subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that particular classes or interfaces are never used.
Rationale: Helps reduce coupling on concrete classes.
For additional restriction of type usage see also: IllegalInstantiation, IllegalImport

tr.td: Control whether to validate abstract class names.
Specify classes that should not be used as types in variable declarations, return values or parameters.

td.code: HashMap, HashSet, LinkedHashMap, LinkedHashSet, TreeMap, TreeSet, java.util.HashMap, java.util.HashSet, java.util.LinkedHashMap, java.util.LinkedHashSet, java.util.TreeMap, java.util.TreeSet

tr.td: Define abstract classes that may be used as types.
Specify methods that should not be checked.
Specify RegExp for illegal abstract class names.
Control whether to check only methods and fields with any of the specified modifiers. This property does not affect method calls nor method references nor record components.

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p:
It is possible to set illegal class names via short or
canonical name. Specifying illegal type invokes analyzing imports and Check puts violations at corresponding declarations (of variables, methods or parameters). This helps to avoid ambiguous cases, e.g.: java.awt.List was set as illegal class name, then, code like:
In most cases it's justified to put following classes to illegalClassNames:
as methods that are differ from interface methods are rarely used, so in most cases user will benefit from checking for them.
